heading: Deaths
txt: Percy Bysshe Shelley, English poet and playwright (b. 1792)

entities.title: Percy Bysshe Shelley
entities.description: Percy Bysshe Shelley was one of the major English Romantic poets. American literary critic Harold Bloom describes him as "a superb craftsman, a lyric poet without rival, and surely one of the most advanced sceptical intellects ever to write a poem." A radical in his poetry as well as in his political and social views, Shelley did not achieve fame during his lifetime, but recognition of his achieve

heading: Deaths
txt: Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge (b. 1774)

entities.title: Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge
entities.description: Prince Adolphus, Duke of Cambridge, was the tenth child and seventh son of the British king George III and Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz. He held the title of Duke of Cambridge from 1801 until his death. He also served as Viceroy of Hanover on behalf of his brothers George IV and William IV. His granddaughter Princess Victoria Mary of Teck, daughter of Princess Mary Adelaide, was the wife of K

heading: Deaths
txt: Oscar I of Sweden (b. 1799)

entities.title: Oscar I of Sweden
entities.description: Oscar I was King of Sweden and Norway from 8 March 1844 until his death. He was the second monarch of the House of Bernadotte.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franz Xaver Winterhalter, German painter and lithographer (b. 1805)

entities.title: Franz Xaver Winterhalter
entities.description: Franz Xaver Winterhalter was a German painter and lithographer, known for his flattering portraits of royalty and upper-class society in the mid-19th century. His name has become associated with fashionable court portraiture. Among his best known works are Empress Eugénie Surrounded by her Ladies in Waiting (1855) and the portraits he made of Empress Elisabeth of Austria (1865).

heading: Deaths
txt: Ben Holladay, American businessman (b. 1819)

entities.title: Ben Holladay
entities.description: Benjamin Holladay was an American transportation businessman responsible for creating the Overland Stage to California during the height of the 1849 California Gold Rush. Ben Holladay created a stagecoach empire and he is known in history as the "Stagecoach King". A native of Kentucky, he also was hired as a private courier to General Alexander Doniphan of Missouri. Doniphan refused point-blank to

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Josef Loschmidt, Austrian chemist and physicist (b. 1821)

entities.title: Johann Josef Loschmidt
entities.description: Johann Josef Loschmidt, who referred to himself mostly as Josef Loschmidt, was a notable Austrian scientist who performed ground-breaking work in chemistry, physics, and crystal forms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Kittredge, American violinist and composer (b. 1834)

entities.title: Walter Kittredge
entities.description: Walter Kittredge, was a famous musician during the American Civil War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Hémon, French-Canadian author (b. 1880)

entities.title: Louis Hémon
entities.description: Louis Hémon, was a French writer best known for his novel Maria Chapdelaine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Thomson, Canadian painter (b. 1877)

entities.title: Tom Thomson
entities.description: Thomas John Thomson was a Canadian artist active in the early 20th century. During his short career he produced roughly 400 oil sketches on small wood panels along with around 50 larger works on canvas. heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph Ward, Australian-New Zealand businessman and politician, 17th Prime Minister of New Zealand (b. 1856)

entities.title: Joseph Ward
entities.description: Sir Joseph George Ward, 1st Baronet, of Wellington, was a New Zealand politician who served as the 17th Prime Minister of New Zealand from 1906 to 1912 and from 1928 to 1930. He was a dominant figure in the Liberal and United ministries of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

entities.title: Prime Minister of New Zealand
entities.description: The prime minister of New Zealand is the head of government of New Zealand. The incumbent prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, took office on 26 October 2017.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anthony Hope, English author and playwright (b. 1863)

entities.title: Anthony Hope
entities.description: Sir Anthony Hope Hawkins, better known as Anthony Hope, was a British novelist and playwright. He was a prolific writer, especially of adventure novels but he is remembered predominantly for only two books: The Prisoner of Zenda (1894) and its sequel Rupert of Hentzau (1898). heading: Deaths
txt: Benjamin Baillaud, French astronomer and academic (b. 1848)

entities.title: Benjamin Baillaud
entities.description: Édouard Benjamin Baillaud was a French astronomer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Havelock Ellis, English psychologist and author (b. 1859)

entities.title: Havelock Ellis
entities.description: Henry Havelock Ellis was an English physician, eugenicist, writer, progressive intellectual and social reformer who studied human sexuality. He co-wrote the first medical textbook in English on homosexuality in 1897, and also published works on a variety of sexual practices and inclinations, as well as on transgender psychology. He is credited with introducing the notions of narcissism and autoero

heading: Deaths
txt: Moses Schorr, Polish rabbi, historian, and politician (b. 1874)

entities.title: Moses Schorr
entities.description: Moses Schorr, Polish: Mojżesz Schorr was a rabbi, Polish historian, politician, Bible scholar, assyriologist and orientalist. Schorr was one of the top experts on the history of the Jews in Poland. He was the first Jewish researcher of Polish archives, historical sources, and pinkasim. The president of the 13th district B'nai B'rith Poland, he was a humanist and modern rabbi who ministered the cen

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Franchet d'Espèrey, Algerian-French general (b. 1856)

entities.title: Louis Franchet d'Espèrey
entities.description: Louis Félix Marie François Franchet d'Espèrey was a French general during World War I. As commander of the large Allied army based at Salonika, he conducted the successful Macedonian campaign, which caused the collapse of the Southern Front and contributed to the armistice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Refik Saydam, Turkish physician and politician, 5th Prime Minister of Turkey (b. 1881)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Turkey
entities.description: The Prime Minister of the Republic of Turkey was the head of government of the Republic of Turkey from 1920 to 2018, who led a political coalition in the Turkish Parliament and presided over the cabinet. Throughout the political history of Turkey, functions and powers of the post had changed occasionally.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Moulin, French soldier (b. 1899)

entities.title: Jean Moulin
entities.description: Jean Pierre Moulin was a French civil servant who served as the first President of the National Council of the Resistance during World War II from 23 May 1943 until his death less than two months later.

heading: Deaths
txt: Othmar Spann, Austrian sociologist, economist, and philosopher (b. 1878)

entities.title: Othmar Spann
entities.description: Othmar Spann was a conservative Austrian philosopher, sociologist and economist whose radical anti-liberal and anti-socialist views, based on early 19th century Romantic ideas expressed by Adam Müller et al. and popularized in his books and lecture courses, helped antagonise political factions in Austria during the interwar years.

heading: Deaths
txt: August Alle, Estonian lawyer, author, and poet (b. 1890)

entities.title: August Alle
entities.description: August Alle was an Estonian writer.

txt: Giovanni Papini, Italian journalist, author, and critic (b. 1881)

entities.title: Giovanni Papini
entities.description: Giovanni Papini was an Italian journalist, essayist, novelist, short story writer, poet, literary critic, and philosopher. A controversial literary figure of the early and mid-twentieth century, he was the earliest and most enthusiastic representative and promoter of Italian pragmatism. heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Sigismund Stribling, American lawyer and author (b. 1881)

entities.title: Thomas Sigismund Stribling
entities.description: Thomas Sigismund Stribling was an American writer and lawyer who published under the name T.S. Stribling. He won the Pulitzer Prize for the Novel in 1933 for his novel The Store.

heading: Deaths
txt: Désiré Mérchez, French swimmer and water polo player (b. 1882)

entities.title: Désiré Mérchez
entities.description: Désiré Alfred Mérchez was a male French swimmer and water polo player who competed in the 1900 Summer Olympics. He was born in Lille and died in Nice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kurt Reidemeister, German mathematician connected to the Vienna Circle (b. 1893)

entities.title: Kurt Reidemeister
entities.description: Kurt Werner Friedrich Reidemeister was a mathematician born in Braunschweig (Brunswick), Germany.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ghassan Kanafani, Palestinian writer and politician (b. 1936)

entities.title: Ghassan Kanafani
entities.description: Ghassan Kanafani was a Palestinian author and a leading member of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP). On 8 July 1972, he was assassinated by Mossad as a response to the Lod airport massacre.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gene L. Coon, American screenwriter and producer (b. 1924)

entities.title: Gene L. Coon
entities.description: Eugene Lee Coon was an American screenwriter, television producer and novelist. He is best remembered for his work on the original Star Trek series, especially as its showrunner where he was responsible for both its idealistic tone and various key elements of the franchise.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ben-Zion Dinur, Russian-Israeli educator and politician, 4th Education Minister of Israel (b. 1884)

entities.title: Education Minister of Israel
entities.description: The Israeli Ministry of Education is the branch of government charged with overseeing public education institutions in Israel. The department is headed by the Minister of Education, who is a member of the cabinet. The ministry has previously included culture and sport, although this is now covered by the Ministry of Culture and Sport.

txt: Wilfred Rhodes, English cricketer and coach (b. 1877)

entities.description: Shinichiro Tomonaga , usually cited as Sin-Itiro Tomonaga in English, was a Japanese physicist, influential in the development of quantum electrodynamics, work for which he was jointly awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1965 along with Richard Feynman and Julian Schwinger.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for mankind in the field of physics. txt: Michael Wilding, English actor (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Hallahan, American baseball player (b. 1902)

entities.title: Bill Hallahan
entities.description: William Anthony Hallahan was an American left-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball during the 1920s and 1930s. Nicknamed "Wild Bill" because of his lack of control on the mound—he twice led the National League in bases on balls—Hallahan nevertheless was one of the pitching stars of the 1931 World Series and pitched his finest in postseason competition.

heading: Deaths
txt: Phil Foster, American actor and screenwriter (b. 1913)

entities.title: Phil Foster
entities.description: Phil Foster was an American actor and performer, best known for his portrayal of Frank DeFazio in Laverne & Shirley.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean-Paul Le Chanois, French actor, director, and screenwriter (b. 1909)

heading: Deaths
txt: Skeeter Webb, American baseball player and manager (b. 1909)

entities.title: Skeeter Webb
entities.description: James Laverne "Skeeter" Webb was an American professional baseball infielder in Major League Baseball from 1932 to 1949. He played 12 seasons with the St. Louis Cardinals, Cleveland Indians, Chicago White Sox, Detroit Tigers, and Philadelphia Athletics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lionel Chevrier, Canadian lawyer and politician, 27th Canadian Minister of Justice (b. 1903)

entities.title: Lionel Chevrier
entities.description: Lionel Chevrier, was a Canadian Member of Parliament and cabinet minister.

entities.title: Minister of Justice (Canada)

entities.description: James Grover Franciscus was an American actor, known for his roles in feature films and in six television series: Mr. Novak, The Naked City, The Investigators, Longstreet, Doc Elliot, and Hunter.

heading: Deaths
txt: Christian-Jaque, French director and screenwriter (b. 1904)

entities.title: Christian-Jaque
entities.description: Christian-Jaque was a French filmmaker. From 1954 to 1959, he was married to actress Martine Carol, who starred in several of his films, including Lucrèce Borgia (1953), Madame du Barry (1954), and Nana (1955).

heading: Deaths
txt: Kim Il-sung, North Korean commander and politician, President of North Korea (b. 1912)

entities.title: President of North Korea
entities.description: Eternal leaders of Juche Korea refers to the practice of granting posthumous titles to deceased leaders of North Korea. The phrase "Eternal leaders of Juche Korea" was established by a line in the preamble to the Constitution, as amended on 30 June 2016, and in subsequent revisions.

heading: Deaths
txt: Irene Prador, Austrian-born actress and writer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Irene Prador
entities.description: Irene Prador was an Austrian-born actress and writer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lilí Álvarez, Spanish tennis player, author, and feminist (b. 1905)

entities.title: Lilí Álvarez
entities.description: Elia Maria González-Álvarez y López-Chicheri, also known as Lilí Álvarez, was a Spanish multi-sport competitor, an international tennis champion, an author, feminist and a journalist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pete Conrad, American captain, pilot, and astronaut (b. 1930)

entities.title: Pete Conrad
entities.description: Charles "Pete" Conrad Jr. was an American NASA astronaut, aeronautical engineer, naval officer and aviator, test pilot, and commanded the Apollo 12 space mission, on which he became the third person to walk on the Moon. Conrad was selected in NASA's second astronaut class in 1962.

heading: Deaths
txt: John O'Shea, New Zealand director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1920)

entities.title: John O'Shea (director)
entities.description: John Dempsey O'Shea was a New Zealand independent filmmaker; he was a director, producer, writer and actor. He produced the only three feature films that were made in New Zealand between 1940 and 1970.

txt: Ward Kimball, American animator and trombonist (b. 1914)

entities.title: Ward Kimball
entities.description: Ward Walrath Kimball was an American animator employed by Walt Disney Animation Studios. He was part of Walt Disney's main team of animators, known collectively as Disney's Nine Old Men. His films have been honored with two Academy Awards for Best Animated Short Film.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paula Danziger, American author and educator (b. 1944)

entities.title: Paula Danziger
entities.description: Paula Danziger was an American children's author. She wrote more than 30 books, including her 1974 debut The Cat Ate My Gymsuit, for children's and young adult audiences. At the time of her death, all her books were still in print; they had been published in 53 countries and in 14 languages.

entities.description: Chandra Shekhar Singh was an Indian politician who served as the eighth Prime Minister of India, between 10 November 1990 and 21 June 1991. The prime minister is the chief adviser to the President of India and the head of the Union Council of Ministers. heading: Deaths
txt: John Templeton, American-born British businessman and philanthropist (b. 1912)

entities.title: John Templeton
entities.description: Sir John Marks Templeton was an American-born British investor, banker, fund manager, and philanthropist. In 1954, he entered the mutual fund market and created the Templeton Growth Fund, which averaged growth over 15% per year for 38 years. A pioneer of emerging market investing in the 1960s, Money magazine named him "arguably the greatest global stock picker of the century" in 1999.

heading: Deaths
txt: Midnight, American singer-songwriter (b. 1962)

entities.title: Midnight (musician)
entities.description: Midnight was an American musician best known for being the vocalist of Crimson Glory. The band became known for Midnight's "ear-shattering screams", which drew comparisons to Geoff Tate, and "painfully strident delivery."

entities.title: Roberts Blossom
entities.description: Roberts Scott Blossom was an American character actor, and poet of theatre, film, and television. He was best known for his roles as Old Man Marley in Home Alone (1990) and as Ezra Cobb in the horror film Deranged (1974). entities.title: Governor of Idaho
entities.description: The Governor of Idaho is the head of the executive branch of Idaho's state government and commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The officeholder has the duty to see state laws are executed, power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Idaho Legislature. The current Governor of Idaho is Republican Brad Little, who took office on January 7, 2019.

entities.title: Abdul Sattar Edhi
entities.description: Abdul Sattar Edhi NI LPP GPA was a Pakistani humanitarian, philanthropist and ascetic who founded the Edhi Foundation, which runs the world's largest volunteer ambulance network, along with various homeless shelters, animal shelters, rehabilitation centres, and orphanages across Pakistan. Following his death, his son Faisal Edhi took over as head of the Edhi Foundation.
